rawContent:
And if your reply to this is, "Why don't you focus on Trump?", here's the answer: The Democrats already have the votes of people who find Trump repellent. 

The votes they need are from people who are open to voting for a Democrat, but who don't think Biden is up to the job. Those people exist. We can see them: https://t.co/LyCFmN3bqi

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
A lot right now hinges on whether Democrats understand Biden's modest post-debate drop in polls as evidence that the debate didn't matter or evidence that Biden was already polling near the floor for a 100% name ID Democrat running against Donald Trump.

Evidence for the latter is that Biden was, and still is, polling well behind Dem Senate and House candidates. There are a lot of voters willing to vote for a Democrat who don't want to vote for Biden. We can see them.

Evidence for the former is that subbing in Newsom/Whitmer/Klobuchar/Buttigieg etc doesn't lead to dramatically different numbers in head-to-head polls. I've talked to pollsters who say this is just name ID but it's made the Biden team's job a lot easier.

What's telling is that frontline House Dems and purple state Senate Dems are the ones shifting against Biden, fearing him a drag on their chances. If you'd asked me a year ago whether Biden would have more support from the Squad than from Michael Bennet and Tammy Baldwin and Jon Tester, well, I know what I'd have picked. But I'd have been wrong.

rawContent:
What I’m hearing from congressional Democrats about President Biden is this: He has done nothing to allay their fears. But his defiance — and fury — has been enough to stay their hand.

This is arguably the worst of all worlds: Democrats realize they are drifting toward a grim march to defeat led by a candidate they’ve lost faith in. But they don’t have a plan to do anything about it.

Congressional Democrats aren’t yet at the point where they’re going to abandon Biden en masse. Nor are they at the point where their confidence in him is restored. They need some process that’ll get them to one side or the other, and fast. Here's one suggestion, building off something Senator Bernie Sanders said: https://t.co/FEniYOEa6Q

rawContent: This gets at a long-term problem for crypto, which is that it has defined "trust" in a really unusual way. A "trustless" system isn't one in which you're at pretty high-risk of getting your money stolen, or being scammed out of it.

user.rawDescription: Writer @TheAtlantic. "Plain English" podcast host @Ringer. Mondays on NPR's @hereandnow. Co-writing a book about abundance.

quotedTweet.rawContent:
In the last 37 weeks, there have been 38 large crypto hacks that have stolen or destroyed $3 billion in crypto wealth.

In all of 2021, hacks stole or destroyed just over $3 billion in crypto value.

So, both the rate and scale of hacking is getting worse

https://t.co/66tOigoWwT

rawContent:
I've been talking to students today about how a problem in media is we reward the worst lawmakers with the most coverage. 

And I want to be the change I seek in the world, but I also want to make jokes about Madison Cawthorn saying his fellow GOPers keep inviting him to orgies.

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
Politicians acting aberrantly is newsworthy. 

But when that's the one reliable path new lawmakers have for getting attention, it becomes an incentive for them to act aberrantly, and so you get more of them doing it.

rawContent:
I suspect, long-run, South Korea will still be a success story. Holding COVID back till your country is nearly entirely vaccinated and the dominant variant is milder will save a lot of lives!

But as Derek says, and the graph reveals, you can't hold Covid back forever.

user.rawDescription: Writer @TheAtlantic. "Plain English" podcast host @Ringer. Mondays on NPR's @hereandnow. Co-writing a book about abundance.

quotedTweet.rawContent:
In 2020 and 2021, South Korea was a global COVID success story. 

In January 2022, the US had 13x more cases per capita. 

Today, the US has just 1.3x more cases per capita. 

Korea’s success, *by this one metric*, has updated negatively by an order of magnitude. https://t.co/i7YxkPTWTC

rawContent:
Seeing blog essays develop a business model is really cool. 

But blogging wasn't about individual blogs. It was about the connections and interactions and pathways between them, which mainly came through links and short comments/responses.

Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
RT @DKThomp: Americans were skeptical of the Apollo project, skeptical of polio vaccines, and skeptical of computers. 

It’s possible that new ideas in science and technology often thrive not *because of* the polling public’s innate love of new ideas but *in spite of* our chronic skepticism.

rawContent:
The implied population-level infection numbers here are just wild. Avoiding this thing will be very, very hard, in a way I’m not sure our public conversation has caught up to. 

Strong case for being very, very cautious if you have immunocompromised people in your life.

rawContent: Which, again, isn’t to say we shouldn’t be where the UK is on rapid tests. But I think people want to believe there’s a live-life, avoid-Omicron-surge option, and rapid tests are carrying the weight of that hope, when they can’t really bear it.

rawContent: I’ve come to believe that a big part of midterm demobilization for the governing party is that the dynamics of legislative compromise make winning feel like losing; the drip of concessions leave huge accomplishments feeling like barely-worth-it quarter-loaves. (see, Obamacare)

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
That’s another dynamic Democrats need to figure out how to avoid here, though I’m not sure how you do it. 

You want to do big things, celebrate them, win elections, and build on them. Not do big things, hate each other, lose elections, and watch Republicans destroy democracy.

rawContent:
My version of this thread:

In DC, the culture was forged by watching solvable problems prove impossible to solve. 

In SV, the culture was forged by watching (seemingly) impossible problems get (seemingly) solved.

Both places overlearned their experience.

rawContent:
This is, as best I can tell, one of the cultural drivers of the Web3 mania in SV.

It feels to many in SV like an opportunity to wipe the slate clean, to go back to solving impossible problems rather than being the impossible-to-solve problem.

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
And to be clear, I'm not really picking a side here. I've learned from both. 

DC underrates how many political problems could be solved, or at least eased, by better technology.

SV overrates how many problems of power, culture and conflict are actually software problems.

quotedTweet.rawContent: And finally (c) lock-in effects - homeowners in areas with lower house prices find it hard to move to more expensive areas. As do their friends and families. So regions drift apart both economically and socially. 7/n

rawContent:
McConnell ended the filibuster on Supreme Court nominations in order to build the majority that looks likely to overturn Roe.

If Roe is overturned, and Democrats keep Congress, will they end the filibuster so they can enshrine Roe's protections in legislation?

If not, why not?

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent: The asymmetry where Republicans weren't bound by the filibuster in building this Supreme Court but Democrats are bound by it in legislatively responding to its rulings will prove devastating if Democrats don't change it.

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
It always bugs me when people pretend a two party system only represents two views. The parties are full of factions and disagreements. 

Drutman puts it more clearly: The difference is in how and when factions form into coalitions.

user.rawDescription:
Columnist, @NYTOpinion
Author, "Why We're Polarized"
Host of "The Ezra Klein Show" podcast

rawContent:
One weak point of the paper, in my view, is it doesn't grapple with *why* the US clings to an electoral system that we know exacerbates political and ethnic conflict. 

Multiethnic, truly representative democracy is not a shared goal, and our electoral system reflects that...
